channel.title: Comments on: Troubleshooting Blocking 101 on SQL Server
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Dan
item.dc:creator: Dan
item.description: Very interesting post! There are only few articles in the web that analyze problems like this one exposed with such synthetic and, at the same time, deep details. My compliments.
item.content:encoded: Very interesting post! There are only few articles in the web that analyze problems like this one exposed with such synthetic and, at the same time, deep details. My compliments.

item.description: Thanks for finding the typo. Hope you enjoyed the post
item.content:encoded: Thanks for finding the typo. Hope you enjoyed the post

item.title: By: thierry
item.dc:creator: thierry
item.description: the process id for the IX lock is not 166 but 165 ;)
item.content:encoded: the process id for the IX lock is not 166 but 165 ðŸ˜‰

item.title: By: bob
item.dc:creator: bob
item.content:encoded:
Excellent post! I’m struggling with just this issue because of a Access program
that locks a table that my application attempts to use. Now I can just halt the
app if a lock on the table is detected. At least thats how I hope it will work…
